an5.7:1.1: “Mendicants, sentient beings are mostly charmed by sensual pleasures.
an5.7:1.2: When a gentleman has abandoned the scythe and flail and gone forth from the lay life to homelessness, they’re qualified to be called ‘a faithful renunciate from a good family’.
an5.7:1.4: Because a youth can get sensual pleasures of this kind or that.
an5.7:1.5: Now, all sensual pleasures are just reckoned as ‘sensual pleasures’, regardless of whether they’re inferior, average, or superior.
an5.7:1.6: Suppose there was a little baby boy who, because of his nursemaid’s negligence, puts a stick or stone in his mouth.
an5.7:1.7: The nursemaid would very quickly notice
an5.7:1.8: and try to take it out.
an5.7:1.9: If that didn’t work, she’d cradle his head with her left hand, and take it out using a hooked finger of her right hand, even if it drew blood.
an5.7:1.11: I admit she’d know, ‘This will distress the child,
an5.7:1.13: Still, it should be done by a nursemaid who wants what’s best for him, out of kindness and sympathy.
an5.7:1.14: And when the boy has grown up and has enough sense, his nursemaid would not be concerned about him, thinking:
an5.7:1.15: ‘The boy can look after himself. He won’t be negligent.’
an5.7:2.1: In the same way, I still need to look after a mendicant who hasn’t finished developing faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom regarding skillful qualities.
an5.7:2.2: But when a mendicant has finished developing faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom regarding skillful qualities, I need not be concerned, thinking:
an5.7:2.3: ‘They can look after themselves. They won’t be negligent.’”
